title: Krupa: Larkin's impact affirmed by Blashill's bold move
text:
Dylan Larkin (Photo: David Guralnick, Detroit News) 
2 CONNECT 9 TWEET LINKEDIN 3 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Detroit – The Red Wings were on the penalty kill, early in the game Friday at Joe Louis Arena, and they had the Maple Leafs bottled up in their own zone.
They even generated a couple of chances.
It was reminiscent of the days when the Wings penalty killers were so skilled that players such as Steve Yzerman or Sergei Fedorov, paired with Kris Draper or Kirk Maltby, could control the man-advantage situation to the point the team with the extra attacker had to play defense in front of their goalie.
Among the penalty killers this time was the 19-year-old Dylan Larkin.
Larkin's time has come.
Coach Jeff Blashill surprised many when he announced Monday that Larkin made the roster, bucking the Red Wings tradition of seasoning prospects in the minors until all the salt, pepper, rosemary and thyme is applied, seeped in and enhancing the experience.
That Larkin may never see Grand Rapids as a regular starter for the Griffins, again, is a huge affirmation of his talent, maturity and impact.
His impact, as on that shift on the penalty kill, sealed the deal, to Larkin's great credit.
DETROIT NEWS
Dylan Larkin, 19, makes Red Wings roster
But the fact that the move occurred is significant of something else important: Blashill, the second-youngest coach in the NHL, new to the league except for one season as an assistant and the replacement for perhaps the best in the game, is firmly in control of his new gig.
"If he didn't grab the job, the easier thing to do would have been to put him in GR to see where we're at and see how his play goes," Blashill said.
"We just felt – I, specifically, really felt – that he makes us better, and to such an exponential amount that we felt it was that important that he start on the team.
"You could ask around the league and a lot of people would say that the safer thing to do would be to put him in GR. But we just feel like he's in that spot."
Which is not to say the wunderkind, Larkin, would not have made it, regardless.
Mike Babcock traveled to both Europe and Grand Rapids late last season, saying he was watching young Larkin.
General Manager Ken Holland clearly was impressed by Larkin, too. But Holland's determination, ability and demonstrated success in marshaling the organization to prepare young talent to the point it is beyond NHL-ready when it arrives on the Wings' bench seemed likely to prevail.
It is a pattern and practice -- in fact, quite nearly a tradition -- that is clearly frustrating some fans.
The fact of the matter is, however, that a major reason for the continuing success of the Red Wings while rebuilding is Holland's determination that prospects should not fail, when they first arrive.
But what is plain from Larkin making the roster is that two people pushed hardest to get it done -- Larkin and Blashill.
The new coach clearly controls his own roster, by and large. When he presses hard for what he wants, he gets it.
Despite lots of consideration that Larkin was destined for the minors, Blashill was not going to have it that way, especially with Larkin proving the point in just over a month in Detroit and Traverse City.
Blashill is willing to take a risk, buck what is acknowledged as policy and even defy Red Wings tradition, if he believes it helps the club win. When you are working your tail off, especially at an advancing age with a roster still rebuilding after some glorious seasons, you tend to like a guy who leads.
Jeff Blashill on Dylan Larkin: “If a guy made our team better and is going to play minutes, then he was going to make our team."   (Photo: David Guralnick, Detroit News) 
There is no doubt that Larkin sealed the deal, and made the move easier.
When he talked about wanting to be "the best player in the world" since he was a young boy, any knowledgeable listener did not think it was too brash, let alone outrageous bravado. Larkin is that skilled, that self-assured and, right now, he is having considerable impact, almost shift-by-shift.
When he talked about how he believed he left little doubt he should remain with the club at the start of the season, one might note that no prospect has made a similar assertion, in the face of Red Wings policy, practice and even tradition, in some time.
But the bold assertion rang true.
That Blashill discerned the circumstances and made sure his decision became THE decision is a mark of a good coach. It is critical, several days before the start of his first season, in the shadow of a master, that Blashill had the confidence and self-possession to see it through.
It is a new day for the Red Wings in a variety of ways.
In Mike Green and Brad Richards, two significant free agents finally arrived this summer. With Larkin, a young player is instilling the belief the franchise is on the rise, once again, and maybe in ways that can be significant, sooner than anticipated.
And the new coach? Blashill seems eminently in control and it already shows. Dylan Larkin is on the roster.
